001package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful;
002
003import com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.SpriteBatch;
004import com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.glutils.ShaderProgram;
005import com.badlogic.gdx.utils.GdxRuntimeException;
006import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorfulBatch;
007import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorfulSprite;
008
009/**
010 * Shader code to construct a {@link ShaderProgram} that can render the specialized colors produced by the rest of this
011 * library. The shader code is meant for use in a {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.SpriteBatch}; a convenience
012 * method, {@link #makeYCwCmBatch()}, is provided to generate and return a SpriteBatch that uses a correct ShaderProgram.
013 * Many of the shaders here are experimental and meant as a basis for user code, rather than a complete solution.
014 * If you aren't familiar with shaders in libGDX, <a href="https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/wiki/Shaders">see this
015 * libGDX wiki article</a> for more information.
016 * <br>
017 * None of the shaders here specify a {@code #version}, and some combinations of OS, driver, and GPU hardware may
018 * require the version to be set to a specific value. You may need to put:
019 * {@code ShaderProgram.prependVertexCode = "#version 110\n";
020 * ShaderProgram.prependFragmentCode = "#version 110\n";} in your launchers, with whatever version you can support, in
021 * order to avoid some warnings or errors on some systems.
022 * <br>
023 * Many of these shaders would need at least some changing to work with kinds of
024 * {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch} that aren't SpriteBatch (or at least very similar). You should compare
025 * the names of {@code uniform} variables in the vertex and fragment shader if you use a different kind of Batch; if all
026 * of them are the same and there are the same amount, then you should be able to use these shaders without issue.
027 * <br>
028 * Note that you don't need to specify a shader from here at all if you use a ColorfulBatch from this library!
029 * There is a ColorfulBatch in each of the color space subpackages, such as {@code rgb}, {@code oklab}, and {@code ipt}.
030 * All of those allow a multiplicative "tweak" to each color channel before an additive change is applied to that
031 * channel; to contrast, all of the shaders here can only permit one or the other for a given channel. ColorfulBatch may
032 * act oddly if it has to interact with SpriteBatch-specific classes like {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Sprite},
033 * so there are ColorfulSprite classes that also allow setting the "tweak" and additive change per-sprite. Still, it can
034 * be a good idea to use the shaders here if you have an existing SpriteBatch, or want to use the various experimental
035 * shaders as a test-bed.
036 */
037public class Shaders {
038    /**
039     * This is the default vertex shader from libGDX. It is used without change by most of the fragment shaders here.
040     */
041    public static final String vertexShader = "attribute vec4 " + ShaderProgram.POSITION_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
042            + "attribute vec4 " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
043            + "attribute vec2 " + ShaderProgram.TEXCOORD_ATTRIBUTE + "0;\n"
044            + "uniform mat4 u_projTrans;\n"
045            + "varying vec4 v_color;\n"
046            + "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n"
047            + "\n"
048            + "void main()\n"
049            + "{\n"
050            + "   v_color = " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
051            + "   v_color.a = v_color.a * (255.0/254.0);\n"
052            + "   v_texCoords = " + ShaderProgram.TEXCOORD_ATTRIBUTE + "0;\n"
053            + "   gl_Position =  u_projTrans * " + ShaderProgram.POSITION_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
054            + "}\n";
055    /*
056attribute vec4 a_position;
057attribute vec4 a_color;
058attribute vec2 a_texCoord0;
059uniform mat4 u_projTrans;
060varying vec4 v_color;
061varying vec2 v_texCoords;
062
063void main()
064{
065   v_color = a_color;
066   v_color.a = v_color.a * (255.0/254.0);
067   v_texCoords = a_texCoord0;
068   gl_Position =  u_projTrans * a_position;
069}
070     */
071
072    /**
073     * A simple shader that uses additive blending with "normal" RGBA colors (alpha is still multiplicative).
074     * With the default SpriteBatch ShaderProgram, white is the neutral color, 50% gray darkens a color by about 50%,
075     * and black darkens a color to black, but nothing can brighten a color. With this, 50% gray is the neutral color,
076     * white adds 0.5 to the RGB channels (brightening it and also desaturating it), and black subtracts 0.5 from the
077     * RGB channels (darkening and desaturating, but not to black unless the color is already somewhat dark). When
078     * tinting with white, this looks like <a href="https://i.imgur.com/iAb1rig.png">The Mona Lisa on the left</a>, when
079     * tinting with 50% gray, it makes no change, and when tinting with black, it almost reaches all black, but some
080     * faint part of the image is still barely visible.
081     * <br>
082     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
083     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
084     * <br>
085     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
086     */
087    public static final String fragmentShaderRGBA =
088            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
089                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
090                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
091                    "#else\n" +
092                    "#define LOWP \n" +
093                    "#endif\n" +
094                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
095                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
096                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
097                    "void main()\n" +
098                    "{\n" +
099                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
100                    "   gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(tgt.rgb * pow((v_color.rgb + 0.1) * 1.666, vec3(1.5)), v_color.a * tgt.a), 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
101                    "}";
102    /**
103     * A simple shader that uses multiplicative blending with "normal" RGBA colors, and is simpler than
104     * {@link #fragmentShaderRGBA} but can make changes in color smoother. With the default SpriteBatch ShaderProgram,
105     * white is the neutral color, 50% gray darkens a color by about 50%, and black darkens a color to black, but
106     * nothing can brighten a color. With this, 50% gray is the neutral color, white multiplies the RGB channels by
107     * 2.0 (brightening it and slightly desaturating it), and black multiplies the RGB channels by 0 (reducing the color
108     * always to black). When tinting with white, this looks like <a href="https://i.imgur.com/I30jeXv.png">The Mona
109     * Lisa on the left</a>; when tinting with 50% gray, it makes no change, and when tinting with black, it produces an
110     * all-black image.
111     * <br>
112     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
113     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
114     * <br>
115     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
116     * <br>
117     * An earlier version of this attempted to use some useful code by CypherCove in gdx-tween, but the current version
118     * doesn't share any code, and doesn't really do any gamma correction either. It does less... gamma... un-correction
119     * than {@link #fragmentShaderRGBA}, though, so if the source images are gamma-corrected this should be fine.
120     * <br>
121     * This was called {@code fragmentShaderGammaRGBA}, but it doesn't do any gamma-correction now. It still seems quite
122     * smooth. Where {@link #fragmentShaderRGBA} adds the batch color to the pixel colors, this multiplies them.
123     */
124    public static final String fragmentShaderMultiplyRGBA =
125            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
126                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
127                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
128                    "#else\n" +
129                    "#define LOWP \n" +
130                    "#endif\n" +
131                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
132                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
133                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
134                    "void main()\n" +
135                    "{\n" +
136                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D(u_texture, v_texCoords);\n" +
137                    "   gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(tgt.rgb * v_color.rgb * 2.0, v_color.a * tgt.a), 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
138                    "}";
139
140
141    /**
142     * A simple shader that uses additive blending with "normal" RGBA colors (alpha is still multiplicative), and
143     * increases contrast somewhat, making the lightness change more sharply or harshly.
144     * With the default SpriteBatch ShaderProgram, white is the neutral color, 50% gray darkens a color by about 50%,
145     * and black darkens a color to black, but nothing can brighten a color. With this, 50% gray is the neutral color,
146     * white adds 0.5 to the RGB channels (brightening it and also desaturating it), and black subtracts 0.5 from the
147     * RGB channels (darkening and desaturating, but not to black unless the color is already somewhat dark).
148     * <br>
149     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
150     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
151     * <br>
152     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
153     */
154    public static final String fragmentShaderHigherContrastRGBA =
155            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
156                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
157                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
158                    "#else\n" +
159                    "#define LOWP \n" +
160                    "#endif\n" +
161                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
162                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
163                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
164                    "const float contrast =    1.5   ;\n" +
165                    "vec3 barronSpline(vec3 x, float shape) {\n" +
166                    "        const float turning = 0.5;\n" +
167                    "        vec3 d = turning - x;\n" +
168                    "        return mix(\n" +
169                    "          ((1. - turning) * (x - 1.)) / (1. - (x + shape * d)) + 1.,\n" +
170                    "          (turning * x) / (1.0e-20 + (x + shape * d)),\n" +
171                    "          step(0.0, d));\n" +
172                    "}\n" +
173                    "void main()\n" +
174                    "{\n" +
175                    "  vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
176                    "  tgt.rgb = barronSpline(clamp(tgt.rgb + v_color.rgb, 0.0, 1.0), contrast);\n" +
177                    "  tgt.a *= v_color.a;\n" +
178                    "  gl_FragColor = tgt;\n" +
179                    "}";
180
181    /**
182     * A simple shader that uses additive blending with "normal" RGBA colors (alpha is still multiplicative), and
183     * reduces contrast somewhat, making the lightness more murky and uniform.
184     * With the default SpriteBatch ShaderProgram, white is the neutral color, 50% gray darkens a color by about 50%,
185     * and black darkens a color to black, but nothing can brighten a color. With this, 50% gray is the neutral color,
186     * white adds 0.5 to the RGB channels (brightening it and also desaturating it), and black subtracts 0.5 from the
187     * RGB channels (darkening and desaturating, but not to black unless the color is already somewhat dark).
188     * <br>
189     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
190     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
191     * <br>
192     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
193     */
194    public static final String fragmentShaderLowerContrastRGBA = fragmentShaderHigherContrastRGBA.replace("   1.5   ", "0.5");
195
196    //// save the result as shader, and set it on your batch with
197    // ShaderProgram shader = makeRGBAShader();
198    // batch.setShader(shader)
199    /**
200     * A simple helper method that builds the simplest shader here; this shader allows tinting with light colors to
201     * lighten an image. You can assign the result to a SpriteBatch with its
202     * {@link SpriteBatch#setShader(ShaderProgram)} method.
203     * <br>
204     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
205     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
206     * @return a ShaderProgram that uses the RGBA shader {@link #fragmentShaderRGBA}
207     */
208    public static ShaderProgram makeRGBAShader()
209    {
210        ShaderProgram shader = new ShaderProgram(vertexShader, fragmentShaderRGBA);
211        if(!shader.isCompiled())
212            throw new GdxRuntimeException("Couldn't compile shader: " + shader.getLog());
213        return shader;
214    }
215    /**
216     * A simple helper method that builds the simplest shader here; this shader allows tinting with light colors to
217     * lighten an image, and also smooths changes well. You can assign the result to a SpriteBatch with its
218     * {@link SpriteBatch#setShader(ShaderProgram)} method.
219     * <br>
220     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
221     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
222     * <br>
223     * This was called {@code makeGammaRGBAShader}, but because it doesn't currently do any gamma correction, naming it
224     * {@code makeMultiplyRGBAShader} seems more appropriate. {@link #makeRGBAShader()} is the additive counterpart.
225     * @return a ShaderProgram that uses the RGBA shader {@link #fragmentShaderMultiplyRGBA}
226     */
227    public static ShaderProgram makeMultiplyRGBAShader()
228    {
229        ShaderProgram shader = new ShaderProgram(vertexShader, fragmentShaderMultiplyRGBA);
230        if(!shader.isCompiled())
231            throw new GdxRuntimeException("Couldn't compile shader: " + shader.getLog());
232        return shader;
233    }
234    /**
235     * Prepares and returns a new SpriteBatch that uses {@link #vertexShader} and {@link #fragmentShaderHigherContrastRGBA}
236     * from this class, making it able to render RGBA colors from the libGDX or the rgb package. This also takes a
237     * {@code contrast} parameter, which modifies the contrast in the higher-contrast fragment shader; if greater than
238     * 1.0 it will make light colors lighter and dark colors darker, while if it is less than 1.0 it will make all but
239     * the darkest colors closer to the upper-middle-range of lightness. If you want to adjust contrast per-sprite, use
240     * a {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorfulBatch} (those can adjust colors in more ways); you can
241     * simply use {@code new ColorfulBatch()} to make one of those. Note that a SpriteBatch like this produces
242     * won't be able to render a {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorfulSprite}, but ColorfulBatch can.
243     * ColorfulBatch also will calculate contrast differently from the shader this uses. It also takes a contrast in its
244     * tweak value that is limited to a 0.0 to 1.0 range, rather than 0.0 on up here. One potential use for this method
245     * is to "deep-fry" a scene's image by using very high contrast (5.0 or higher).
246     * <br>
247     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
248     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
249     * @param contrast how much contrast should be emphasized; higher than 1.0 is more contrasting, and this should usually be between 0.1 and 5.0
250     * @return a freshly allocated SpriteBatch that will also have a new ShaderProgram for rendering RGB with contrast
251     */
252    public static SpriteBatch makeRGBABatch(final float contrast)
253    {
254        ShaderProgram shader = new ShaderProgram(vertexShader, fragmentShaderHigherContrastRGBA.replace("   1.5   ", Float.toString(Math.max(contrast, 0.0f))));
255        if(!shader.isCompiled())
256            throw new GdxRuntimeException("Couldn't compile shader: " + shader.getLog());
257        return new SpriteBatch(1000, shader);
258    }
259
260    /**
261     * Where the magic happens; this converts a batch color from the YCwCm format (used by colorful's ycwcm package) to
262     * RGBA. The vertex color will be split up into 4 channels just as a normal shader does, but the channels here are
263     * luma, chromatic warmth, chromatic mildness, and alpha; alpha acts just like a typical RGBA shader, but the others
264     * are additive instead of multiplicative, with 0.5 as a neutral value. This does not support the "tweak" features
265     * that {@link ColorfulBatch} does, which include multiplicative counterparts to the additive operations this
266     * supports on luma, chromatic warmth, and chromatic mildness, plus a contrast adjustment. If you want to adjust
267     * contrast globally, you can use {@link #makeYCwCmBatch(float)} to set the contrast for a new Batch with a new shader.
268     * <br>
269     * You can generate YCwCm colors using any of various methods in the {@code ycwcm} package, such as
270     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}.
271     * <br>
272     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
273     * <br>
274     * This was called {@code fragmentShader}, a name which dates back to when this was the only one in this file. It is
275     * not the only one anymore.
276     */
277    public static final String fragmentShaderYCwCm =
278            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
279                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
280                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
281                    "#else\n" +
282                    "#define LOWP \n" +
283                    "#endif\n" +
284                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
285                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
286                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
287                    "const vec3 bright = vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125);\n" +
288                    "void main()\n" +
289                    "{\n" +
290                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
291                    "////use the following line to match the color exactly\n" +
292                    "   vec3 ycc = vec3(v_color.r - 0.5 + dot(tgt.rgb, bright), ((v_color.g - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.r - tgt.b), ((v_color.b - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.g - tgt.b));\n" +
293                    "////use the following line to increase contrast\n" +
294                    "//   vec3 ycc = vec3(v_color.r * dot(sin(tgt.rgb * 1.5707963267948966) * sqrt(tgt.rgb), bright), ((v_color.g - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.r - tgt.b), ((v_color.b - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.g - tgt.b));\n" +
295                    "////use the following line to increase contrast more\n" +
296                    "//   vec3 ycc = vec3(v_color.r * pow(dot(tgt.rgb, bright), 1.25), ((v_color.g - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.r - tgt.b), ((v_color.b - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.g - tgt.b));\n" +
297                    //uses a specific matrix (related to bright, above) multiplied with ycc to get back to rgb.
298                    "   gl_FragColor = vec4( (clamp(mat3(1.0, 1.0, 1.0, 0.625, -0.375, -0.375, -0.5, 0.5, -0.5) * ycc, 0.0, 1.0)), v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
299                    "}";
300    /**
301     * A variant on {@link #fragmentShaderYCwCm} that adjusts luma to make mid-range colors darker, while keeping light
302     * colors light. This is not the same as {@link ColorfulBatch} even when the contrast for ColorfulBatch's tweak is
303     * the same as what this uses (1.375 here, which is roughly 0.875f in a tweak value). ColorfulBatch does some work
304     * in the vertex shader so it may be a little faster than this approach, and it seems to have less severe effects on
305     * the overall brightness of an image that has adjusted contrast.
306     * <br>
307     * You can generate YCwCm colors using any of various methods in the {@code ycwcm} package, such as
308     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}.
309     * <br>
310     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
311     */
312    public static final String fragmentShaderHigherContrast =
313            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
314                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
315                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
316                    "#else\n" +
317                    "#define LOWP \n" +
318                    "#endif\n" +
319                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
320                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
321                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
322                    "const float contrast =    1.375   ; // You can make contrast a uniform if you want.\n" +
323                    "const vec3 bright = vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125) * (4.0 / 3.0);\n" +
324                    "void main()\n" +
325                    "{\n" +
326                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
327                    "   vec3 ycc = vec3(v_color.r - 0.5 + pow(dot(tgt.rgb, bright), contrast) * 0.75, ((v_color.g - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.r - tgt.b), ((v_color.b - 0.5) * 2.0 + tgt.g - tgt.b));\n" +
328                    "   gl_FragColor = vec4( (clamp(mat3(1.0, 1.0, 1.0, 0.625, -0.375, -0.375, -0.5, 0.5, -0.5) * ycc, 0.0, 1.0)), v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
329                    "}";
330
331    /**
332     * An alternative shader that effectively reduces luma contrast, bringing all but the darkest colors to the
333     * upper-mid luma range. This is not the same as {@link ColorfulBatch} even when the contrast for ColorfulBatch's
334     * tweak is the same as what this uses (0.625 here, which is roughly 0.125f in a tweak value). ColorfulBatch does
335     * some work in the vertex shader so it may be a little faster than this approach, and it seems to have less severe
336     * effects on the overall brightness of an image that has adjusted contrast.
337     * <br>
338     * You can generate YCwCm colors using any of various methods in the {@code ycwcm} package, such as
339     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}.
340     * <br>
341     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
342     */
343    public static final String fragmentShaderLowerContrast = fragmentShaderHigherContrast.replace("   1.375   ", "0.625");
344
345    /**
346     * Prepares and returns a new SpriteBatch that uses the default {@link #vertexShader} and {@link #fragmentShaderYCwCm}
347     * from this class, making it able to render YCwCm colors from the ycwcm package. It won't be a
348     * {@link ColorfulBatch} (those can adjust colors in more ways); you can simply use {@code new ColorfulBatch()} to
349     * make one of those. Note that a SpriteBatch like this produces won't be able to render a {@link ColorfulSprite},
350     * but ColorfulBatch can.
351     * <br>
352     * You can generate YCwCm colors using any of various methods in the {@code ycwcm} package, such as
353     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}.
354     * @return a freshly allocated SpriteBatch that will also have a new ShaderProgram for rendering YCwCm
355     */
356    public static SpriteBatch makeYCwCmBatch()
357    {
358        ShaderProgram shader = new ShaderProgram(vertexShader, fragmentShaderYCwCm);
359        if(!shader.isCompiled())
360            throw new GdxRuntimeException("Couldn't compile shader: " + shader.getLog());
361        return new SpriteBatch(1000, shader);
362    }
363
364    /**
365     * Prepares and returns a new SpriteBatch that uses the default {@link #vertexShader} and {@link #fragmentShaderYCwCm}
366     * from this class, making it able to render YCwCm colors from the ycwcm package. This also takes a
367     * {@code contrast} parameter; if greater than 1.0 it will make light colors lighter and dark colors darker, while
368     * if it is less than 1.0 it will make all but the darkest colors closer to the upper-middle-range of lightness.
369     * If you want to adjust contrast per-sprite, use a {@link ColorfulBatch} (those can adjust colors in more ways);
370     * you can simply use {@code new ColorfulBatch()} to make one of those. Note that a SpriteBatch like this produces
371     * won't be able to render a {@link ColorfulSprite}, but ColorfulBatch can. ColorfulBatch also will calculate
372     * contrast differently from the shader this uses, including doing some work in the vertex shader (which may be
373     * faster). It also takes a contrast in its tweak value that is limited to a 0.0 to 1.0 range, rather than 0.1 to
374     * 2.0 here (this can technically tolerate 0.01 to 10.0, but those extremes aren't recommended).
375     * <br>
376     * You can generate YCwCm colors using any of various methods in the {@code ycwcm} package, such as
377     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ycwcm.ColorTools#ycwcm(float, float, float, float)}.
378     * @param contrast how much contrast should be emphasized; higher than 1.0 is more contrasting, and this should usually be between 0.1 and 2.0
379     * @return a freshly allocated SpriteBatch that will also have a new ShaderProgram for rendering YCwCm
380     */
381    public static SpriteBatch makeYCwCmBatch(final float contrast)
382    {
383        ShaderProgram shader = new ShaderProgram(vertexShader, fragmentShaderHigherContrast.replace("   1.375   ", Float.toString(Math.min(Math.max(contrast, 0.01f), 10f))));
384        if(!shader.isCompiled())
385            throw new GdxRuntimeException("Couldn't compile shader: " + shader.getLog());
386        return new SpriteBatch(1000, shader);
387    }
388
389    /**
390     * Prepares and returns a new SpriteBatch that uses {@link #vertexShaderHSLC} and {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC}
391     * from this class, making it interpret the SpriteBatch's color, as set by 
392     * {@link SpriteBatch#setColor(float, float, float, float)}, to be hue rotation, saturation change, lightness
393     * change, and contrast change. All of these are neutral when their value is 0.5f. Hue rotates clockwise or
394     * counterclockwise when it goes toward 0.0, and the other way when it goes toward 1.0; 0.0 and 1.0 both refer to
395     * the 180 degree rotation, but I don't know which goes which way (it also depends on how you visualize hue).
396     * Saturation becomes more grayscale as it goes towards 0.0, and more vivid as it goes towards 1.0. Lightness gets
397     * darker towards 0.0, lighter towards 1.0 (any lightness above 0.5 will brighten the image, unlike the default
398     * shader and batch color). Contrast affects changes in lightness; low contrast makes all lightness closer to the
399     * mid-range, while high contrast makes even small changes in the mid-range of an image's color have stark lightness
400     * changes in the result. Note, this does not support changing an image's alpha with the batch color.
401     * <br>
402     * You can generate HSLC colors using {@link FloatColors#rgb2hsl(float, float, float, float)}, using the last
403     * parameter to store contrast.
404     * @return a freshly allocated SpriteBatch that will also have a new ShaderProgram for rendering HSLC
405     */
406    public static SpriteBatch makeBatchHSLC()
407    {
408        ShaderProgram shader = new ShaderProgram(vertexShaderHSLC, fragmentShaderHSLC);
409        if(!shader.isCompiled())
410            throw new GdxRuntimeException("Couldn't compile shader: " + shader.getLog());
411        return new SpriteBatch(1000, shader);
412    }
413
414    /**
415     * Similar to {@link #fragmentShaderYCwCm}, but this uses the very perceptually-accurate IPT color space as described by
416     * Ebner and Fairchild, instead of the custom YCwCm color space. IPT doesn't really need that much more computation
417     * to be done by the shader, but tends to make gradual changes in color much smoother. If comparing to YCwCm, then
418     * Y (luma) is like I (intensity) here, so when a Batch color has 0 for I (stored in the r channel), it makes the
419     * image very dark, while if the Batch color has 1 for I, it makes the image very light. Cw and Cm can be graphed
420     * like a color wheel, and in their case, the 4 corners of a square graph are red, yellow, green, and blue. IPT is
421     * less geometrical, and the corners are roughly purple, orange, green, and cyan, while the centers of the edges of
422     * the square are close to red, yellow, green, and blue. <a href="https://i.imgur.com/A3n4qmM.png">See this capture
423     * of the IPT space</a> if you want a better picture. The P (short for protan, a term from ophthalmology) channel
424     * (stored in g) is the left-to-right axis there, with P==0 making colors green or blue (cooler), and P==1 making
425     * colors orange, red, or purple (somewhat warmer). The T (short for tritan, also from ophthalmology) channel
426     * (stored in b) is the down-to-up axis there, with T==0 making colors more blue or purple, and T==1 making colors
427     * more green, yellow, brown, or orange. Where protan can be viewed as going from cool to warm as its value
428     * increases, tritan can be viewed as going from artificial to natural, or perhaps fluid to solid. Alpha is treated
429     * exactly as it is in the standard libGDX fragment shader, with the alpha in the batch color multiplied by the
430     * alpha in the image pixel to get the result alpha.
431     * <br>
432     * You can generate IPT colors using any of various methods in the {@code ipt} package, such as
433     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ipt.ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}. Note that IPT is
434     * intended to share an API with the {@code ipt_hq} package, but IPT_HQ is usually preferred.
435     * <br>
436     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
437     */
438    public static String fragmentShaderIPT =
439            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
440                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
441                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
442                    "#else\n" +
443                    "#define LOWP \n" +
444                    "#endif\n" +
445                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
446                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
447                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
448                    "void main()\n" +
449                    "{\n" +
450                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
451                    "    vec4 adj = v_color;\n" +
452                    "    adj.yz = adj.yz * 2.0 - 0.5;\n" +
453                    "    vec3 ipt = (mat3(0.189786, 0.669665 , 0.286498, 0.576951, -0.73741 , 0.655205, 0.233221, 0.0681367, -0.941748)\n" +
454                    "         * (tgt.rgb)) + adj.xyz - 0.5;\n" +
455                    "    ipt.x = clamp(ipt.x, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
456                    "    ipt.yz = clamp(ipt.yz, -1.0, 1.0);\n" +
457                    "    vec3 back = mat3(0.999779, 1.00015, 0.999769, 1.07094, -0.377744, 0.0629496, 0.324891, 0.220439, -0.809638) * ipt;\n" +
458                    "    gl_FragColor = vec4(clamp(back, 0.0, 1.0), adj.a * tgt.a);\n" +
459                    "}";
460    /**
461     * Just like {@link #fragmentShaderIPT}, but gamma-corrects the input and output RGB values (which improves
462     * lightness uniformity) and uses an exponential step internally to change how colors are distributed within the
463     * gamut. These steps are more computationally expensive than the bare-bones ones in {@link #fragmentShaderIPT}, but
464     * they seem to improve some aspects of color transitions quite a bit.
465     * <br>
466     * You can generate IPT_HQ colors using any of various methods in the {@code ipt_hq} package, such as
467     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ipt_hq.ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}. Note that IPT_HQ is
468     * intended to share an API with the {@code ipt} package, but IPT_HQ is usually preferred.
469     * <br>
470     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
471     */
472    public static String fragmentShaderIPT_HQ =
473            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
474                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
475                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
476                    "#else\n" +
477                    "#define LOWP \n" +
478                    "#endif\n" +
479                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
480                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
481                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
482                    "const vec3 forward = vec3(0.43);\n" +
483                    "const vec3 reverse = vec3(1.0 / 0.43);\n" +
484                    "void main()\n" +
485                    "{\n" +
486                    "  vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
487                    "  vec3 ipt = mat3(0.40000, 4.45500, 0.80560, 0.40000, -4.8510, 0.35720, 0.20000, 0.39600, -1.1628) *" +
488                    "             pow(mat3(0.313921, 0.151693, 0.017753, 0.639468, 0.748209, 0.109468, 0.0465970, 0.1000044, 0.8729690) \n" +
489                    "             * (tgt.rgb * tgt.rgb), forward);\n" +
490                    "  ipt.x = clamp(ipt.x + v_color.x - 0.55, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
491                    "  ipt.yz = clamp(ipt.yz + v_color.yz * 2.0 - 1.0, -1.0, 1.0);\n" +
492                    "  ipt = mat3(1.0, 1.0, 1.0, 0.097569, -0.11388, 0.032615, 0.205226, 0.133217, -0.67689) * ipt;\n" +
493                    "  gl_FragColor = vec4(sqrt(clamp(" +
494                    "                 mat3(5.432622, -1.10517, 0.028104, -4.67910, 2.311198, -0.19466, 0.246257, -0.20588, 1.166325) *\n" +
495                    "                 (sign(ipt) * pow(abs(ipt), reverse))," +
496                    "                 0.0, 1.0)), v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
497                    "}";
498
499    /**
500     * Just like {@link #fragmentShaderIPT_HQ}, but uses the Oklab color space instead of the very similar IPT_HQ one.
501     * This also gamma-corrects the inputs and outputs, though it uses subtly different math internally. Oklab colors
502     * tend to have more variation on their L channel, which represents lightness, than their A or B channels, which
503     * represent green-to-red and blue-to-yellow chromatic axes; indeed, A and B tend to be no more than about 1/6 away
504     * from their middle point at 1/2, which is used for grayscale. This is normal for Oklab, and allows colors to be
505     * compared for approximate difference using Euclidean distance. Importantly, Oklab preserves the meaning of its L
506     * channel (lightness) very well when comparing two arbitrary colors, while also doing well when comparing chroma
507     * (see {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.oklab.ColorTools#chroma(float)}.
508     * <br>
509     * You can generate Oklab colors using any of various methods in the {@code oklab} package, such as
510     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.oklab.ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}.
511     * <br>
512     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
513     */
514    public static String fragmentShaderOklab =
515            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
516                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
517                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
518                    "#else\n" +
519                    "#define LOWP \n" +
520                    "#endif\n" +
521                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
522                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
523                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
524                    "const vec3 forward = vec3(1.0 / 3.0);\n" +
525                    "float toOklab(float L) {\n" +
526                    "        const float shape = 0.64516133, turning = 0.95;\n" +
527                    "        float d = turning - L;\n" +
528                    "        float r = mix(\n" +
529                    "          ((1. - turning) * (L - 1.)) / (1. - (L + shape * d)) + 1.,\n" +
530                    "          (turning * L) / (1.0e-20 + (L + shape * d)),\n" +
531                    "          step(0.0, d));\n" +
532                    "        return r * r;\n" +
533                    "}\n" +
534                    "float fromOklab(float L) {\n" +
535                    "        const float shape = 1.55, turning = 0.95;\n" +
536                    "        L = sqrt(L);\n" +
537                    "        float d = turning - L;\n" +
538                    "        return mix(\n" +
539                    "          ((1. - turning) * (L - 1.)) / (1. - (L + shape * d)) + 1.,\n" +
540                    "          (turning * L) / (1.0e-20 + (L + shape * d)),\n" +
541                    "          step(0.0, d));\n" +
542                    "}\n" +
543//                    "float toOklab(float L) {\n" +
544//                    "  return (L - 1.0) / (1.0 - L * 0.4285714) + 1.0;\n" +
545//                    "}\n" +
546//                    "float fromOklab(float L) {\n" +
547//                    "  return (L - 1.0) / (1.0 + L * 0.75) + 1.0;\n" +
548//                    "}\n" +
549                    "void main()\n" +
550                    "{\n" +
551                    "  vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
552                    "  vec3 lab = mat3(+0.2104542553, +1.9779984951, +0.0259040371, +0.7936177850, -2.4285922050, +0.7827717662, -0.0040720468, +0.4505937099, -0.8086757660) *" +
553                    "             pow(mat3(0.4121656120, 0.2118591070, 0.0883097947, 0.5362752080, 0.6807189584, 0.2818474174, 0.0514575653, 0.1074065790, 0.6302613616) \n" +
554                    "             * (tgt.rgb * tgt.rgb), forward);\n" +
555                    "  lab.x = fromOklab(clamp(toOklab(lab.x) + v_color.r - 0.5, 0.0, 1.0));\n" +
556                    "  lab.yz = clamp(lab.yz + v_color.gb * 2.0 - 1.0, -1.0, 1.0);\n" +
557                    "  lab = mat3(1.0, 1.0, 1.0, +0.3963377774, -0.1055613458, -0.0894841775, +0.2158037573, -0.0638541728, -1.2914855480) * lab;\n" +
558                    "  gl_FragColor = vec4(sqrt(clamp(" +
559                    "                 mat3(+4.0767245293, -1.2681437731, -0.0041119885, -3.3072168827, +2.6093323231, -0.7034763098, +0.2307590544, -0.3411344290, +1.7068625689) *\n" +
560                    "                 (lab * lab * lab)," +
561                    "                 0.0, 1.0)), v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
562                    "}";
563
564    /**
565     * A vertex shader that does the bulk of processing HSI-format batch colors and converting them to a format
566     * {@link #fragmentShaderHSI} can use. Since HSI is only a cylindrical/spherical adaptation of IPT, with identical
567     * I components and the combination of H and S in polar coordinates mapping to P and T in Cartesian coordinates,
568     * the fragment shader this is used with can be any that expects an IPT color (currently only
569     * {@link #fragmentShaderIPT} does this, and it's the same as {@link #fragmentShaderHSI}). This vertex shader does
570     * a lot more than most vertex shaders here, but since it is executed relatively rarely (unless you're drawing many
571     * 1-pixel textures), there shouldn't be a heavy performance penalty.
572     * <br>
573     * There is no special code to generate HSI colors; you can use
574     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ipt.ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}, or any ColorTools
575     * method that generates a packed float color directly from the channel values, to specify hue, saturation,
576     * intensity, and alpha in that order. You can also just specify the batch color directly with
577     * {@link SpriteBatch#setColor(float, float, float, float)}, taking the channels in the same order as above.
578     * <br>
579     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
580     */
581    public static final String vertexShaderHSI = "attribute vec4 " + ShaderProgram.POSITION_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
582        + "attribute vec4 " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
583        + "attribute vec2 " + ShaderProgram.TEXCOORD_ATTRIBUTE + "0;\n"
584        + "uniform mat4 u_projTrans;\n"
585        + "varying vec4 v_color;\n"
586        + "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n"
587        + "const vec3 yellow  = vec3( 0.16155326,0.020876605,-0.26078433 );\n"
588        + "const vec3 magenta = vec3(-0.16136102,0.122068435,-0.070396   );\n"
589        + "const vec3 cyan    = vec3( 0.16420607,0.3481738,   0.104959644);\n"
590        + "void main()\n"
591        + "{\n"
592        + "    v_color = " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
593        + "    v_color.a = " + ShaderProgram.COLOR_ATTRIBUTE + ".a * (255.0/254.0);\n"
594        + "    vec3 hsi = v_color.rgb;\n"
595        + "    v_color.x = (hsi.z - 0.5) * 0.9999;\n"
596        + "    hsi.x *= 6.28318;\n"
597        + "    hsi.y *= 0.5;\n"
598        + "    v_color.y = cos(hsi.x) * hsi.y;\n"
599        + "    v_color.z = sin(hsi.x) * hsi.y;\n"
600        + "    float crMid = dot(cyan.yz, v_color.yz);\n"
601        + "    float mgMid = dot(magenta.yz, v_color.yz);\n"
602        + "    float ybMid = dot(yellow.yz, v_color.yz);\n"
603        + "    float crScale = (v_color.x - 0.5 + step(crMid, 0.0)) * cyan.x / (0.00001 - crMid);\n"
604        + "    float mgScale = (v_color.x + 0.5 - step(mgMid, 0.0)) * magenta.x / (0.00001 - mgMid);\n"
605        + "    float ybScale = (v_color.x - 0.5 + step(ybMid, 0.0)) * yellow.x / (0.00001 - ybMid);\n"
606        + "    float scale = 4.0 * min(crScale, min(mgScale, ybScale));\n"
607        + "    v_color.yz *= scale * length(v_color.yz) / cos(3.14159 * v_color.x);\n"
608        + "    v_color.xyz += 0.5;\n"
609        + "    v_texCoords = " + ShaderProgram.TEXCOORD_ATTRIBUTE + "0;\n"
610        + "    gl_Position =  u_projTrans * " + ShaderProgram.POSITION_ATTRIBUTE + ";\n"
611        + "}\n";
612    /**
613     * This is an alias for {@link #fragmentShaderIPT}. If used with {@link #vertexShaderHSI}, you can specify a batch
614     * color using an HSL-like system.
615     * <br>
616     * There is no special code to generate HSI colors; you can use
617     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.ipt.ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}, or any ColorTools
618     * method that generates a packed float color directly from the channel values, to specify hue, saturation,
619     * intensity, and alpha in that order. You can also just specify the batch color directly with
620     * {@link SpriteBatch#setColor(float, float, float, float)}, taking the channels in the same order as above.
621     * <br>
622     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShaderHSI}.
623     */
624    public static String fragmentShaderHSI = fragmentShaderIPT;
625
626    /**
627     * Not a full shader, this is a snippet used by most of the other HSL-based shaders to implement the complex
628     * rgb2hsl() and hsl2rgb() methods. There are also comments in the code snippet that you can use if you want to
629     * change the distribution of colors across the color wheel.
630     * <br>
631     * <a href="https://gamedev.stackexchange.com/a/59808">Credit to Sam Hocevar</a>.
632     * <br>
633     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
634     */
635    public static final String partialCodeHSL =
636                    "const float eps = 1.0e-10;\n" +
637                    "////Call this to go from the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) to a\n" +
638                    "////different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).\n" +
639                    "//float official2primaries(float hue) {\n" +
640                    "//    return  hue * (  2.137\n" +
641                    "//          + hue * (  0.542\n" +
642                    "//          + hue * (-15.141\n" +
643                    "//          + hue * ( 30.120\n" +
644                    "//          + hue * (-22.541\n" +
645                    "//          + hue *   5.883)))));\n" +
646                    "//}\n" +
647                    "////Call this to go to the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) from a\n" +
648                    "////different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).\n" +
649                    "//float primaries2official(float hue) {\n" +
650                    "//    return  hue * (  0.677\n" +
651                    "//          + hue * ( -0.123\n" +
652                    "//          + hue * (-11.302\n" +
653                    "//          + hue * ( 46.767\n" +
654                    "//          + hue * (-58.493\n" +
655                    "//          + hue *   23.474)))));\n" +
656                    "//}\n" +
657                    "vec4 rgb2hsl(vec4 c)\n" +
658                    "{\n" +
659                    "    const vec4 J = vec4(0.0, -1.0 / 3.0, 2.0 / 3.0, -1.0);\n" +
660                    "    vec4 p = mix(vec4(c.bg, J.wz), vec4(c.gb, J.xy), step(c.b, c.g));\n" +
661                    "    vec4 q = mix(vec4(p.xyw, c.r), vec4(c.r, p.yzx), step(p.x, c.r));\n" +
662                    "    float d = q.x - min(q.w, q.y);\n" +
663                    "    float l = q.x * (1.0 - 0.5 * d / (q.x + eps));\n" +
664                    "    return vec4(abs(q.z + (q.w - q.y) / (6.0 * d + eps)), (q.x - l) / (min(l, 1.0 - l) + eps), l, c.a);\n" +
665                    "}\n" +
666                    "\n" +
667                    "vec4 hsl2rgb(vec4 c)\n" +
668                    "{\n" +
669                    "    const vec4 K = vec4(1.0, 2.0 / 3.0, 1.0 / 3.0, 3.0);\n" +
670                    "    vec3 p = abs(fract(c.x + K.xyz) * 6.0 - K.www);\n" +
671                    "    float v = (c.z + c.y * min(c.z, 1.0 - c.z));\n" +
672                    "    return vec4(v * mix(K.xxx, clamp(p - K.xxx, 0.0, 1.0), 2.0 * (1.0 - c.z / (v + eps))), c.w);\n" +
673                    "}";
674
675    /**
676     * Adjusted-hue version of {@link #partialCodeHSL}, supplying HSL to-and-from RGB conversions with a smaller range
677     * of hue used for cyan and a larger range for orange. Not currently used. This is pretty much only meant so people
678     * reading the source code and trying different variations on HSL can see some of the attempts I made.
679     * <br>
680     * Credit to Sam Hocevar, https://gamedev.stackexchange.com/a/59808 .
681     * <br>
682     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
683     */
684    public static final String partialCodeHSLStretched =
685            "const float eps = 1.0e-10;\n" +
686                    //// maybe not blue enough?
687//                    //Call this to go from the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) to a
688//                    //different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).
689//                    "float official2primaries(float hue) {\n" +
690//                    "    return  hue * (  1.630\n" +
691//                    "          + hue * (  5.937\n" +
692//                    "          + hue * (-38.485\n" +
693//                    "          + hue * ( 76.101\n" +
694//                    "          + hue * (-63.977\n" +
695//                    "          + hue *   19.794)))));\n" +
696//                    "}\n" +
697//                    //Call this to go to the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) from a
698//                    //different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).
699//                    "float primaries2official(float hue) {\n" +
700//                    "    return  hue * (  1.463\n" +
701//                    "          + hue * ( -9.834\n" +
702//                    "          + hue * ( 31.153\n" +
703//                    "          + hue * (-35.066\n" +
704//                    "          + hue *   13.284))));\n" +
705//                    "}\n" +
706                    //// still weirdly high orange
707//                    "float official2primaries(float hue) {\n" +
708//                    "    return  hue * (  2.634\n" +
709//                    "          + hue * ( -4.703\n" +
710//                    "          + hue * (  3.659\n" +
711//                    "          + hue * (  0.829\n" +
712//                    "          + hue *   -1.419))));\n" +
713//                    "}\n" +
714//                    "float primaries2official(float hue) {\n" +
715//                    "    return  hue * (  1.163\n" +
716//                    "          + hue * ( -7.102\n" +
717//                    "          + hue * ( 22.709\n" +
718//                    "          + hue * (-25.502\n" +
719//                    "          + hue *    9.732))));\n" +
720//                    "}\n" +
721//                    "const float ROOT   = 16.0;\n" +
722//                    "const float SQUARE = ROOT * ROOT;\n" +
723                    "float official2primaries(float hue) {\n" +
724//                    "    return (sqrt(hue * 0.9375 + 0.0625) - 0.25) * 1.333;\n" +
725//                    "    return asin(sqrt(hue * SQUARE) * (1.0 / ROOT)) * (2.0 * 3.14159274);\n" +
726
727//                    "    return asin((sqrt(hue * 0.9375 + 0.0625) - 0.25) * 2.666 - 1.0) * 0.318309886 + 0.5;\n" +
728
729//                    "    return sqrt(sin((hue - 0.5) * 3.14159274) * 0.5 + 0.5);\n" +
730//                    "    return pow(hue, 0.5625);\n" +
731//                    "    return sqrt(hue);\n" +
732                    "    return (sqrt(hue + 0.050625) - 0.225) * 1.25;\n" +
733                    "}\n" +
734                    "float primaries2official(float hue) {\n" +
735//                    "    hue = sin((hue) * (0.5 * 3.14159274));\n" +
736//                    "    hue = (hue) * 0.75 + 0.25;\n" +
737                    
738//                    "    hue = sin((hue - 0.5) * 3.14159274);\n" +
739//                    "    hue = (hue + 1.0) * 0.375 + 0.25;\n" +
740//                    "    return (hue * hue - 0.0625) * (1.0 / 0.9375);\n" +
741                    
742//                    "    return asin(hue * hue * 2.0 - 1.0) * 0.318309886 + 0.5;\n" +
743//                    "    return pow(hue, 1.77777);\n" +
744                    "    return pow(hue * 0.8 + 0.225, 2.0) - 0.050625;\n" +
745//                    "    return hue * hue;\n" +
746
747//                    "    hue = sin((hue) * (0.5 * 3.14159274));\n" +
748//                    "    hue = hue * ROOT;\n" +
749//                    "    return (hue * hue) * (1.0 / SQUARE);\n" +
750
751                    "}\n" +
752                    //// way too much orange?
753//                    //Call this to go from the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) to a
754//                    //different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).
755//                    "float official2primaries(float hue) {\n" +
756//                    "    return  hue * (  2.137\n" +
757//                    "          + hue * (  0.542\n" +
758//                    "          + hue * (-15.141\n" +
759//                    "          + hue * ( 30.120\n" +
760//                    "          + hue * (-22.541\n" +
761//                    "          + hue *    5.883)))));\n" +
762//                    "}\n" +
763//                    //Call this to go to the official HSL hue distribution (where blue is opposite yellow) from a
764//                    //different distribution that matches primary colors in painting (where purple is opposite yellow).
765//                    "float primaries2official(float hue) {\n" +
766//                    "    return  hue * (  0.677\n" +
767//                    "          + hue * ( -0.123\n" +
768//                    "          + hue * (-11.302\n" +
769//                    "          + hue * ( 46.767\n" +
770//                    "          + hue * (-58.493\n" +
771//                    "          + hue *   23.474)))));\n" +
772//                    "}\n" +
773                    "vec4 rgb2hsl(vec4 c)\n" +
774                    "{\n" +
775                    "    const vec4 J = vec4(0.0, -1.0 / 3.0, 2.0 / 3.0, -1.0);\n" +
776                    "    vec4 p = mix(vec4(c.bg, J.wz), vec4(c.gb, J.xy), step(c.b, c.g));\n" +
777                    "    vec4 q = mix(vec4(p.xyw, c.r), vec4(c.r, p.yzx), step(p.x, c.r));\n" +
778                    "\n" +
779                    "    float d = q.x - min(q.w, q.y);\n" +
780                    "    float l = q.x * (1.0 - 0.5 * d / (q.x + eps));\n" +
781                    "    return vec4(official2primaries(abs(q.z + (q.w - q.y) / (6.0 * d + eps))), (q.x - l) / (min(l, 1.0 - l) + eps), l, c.a);\n" +
782                    "}\n" +
783                    "\n" +
784                    "vec4 hsl2rgb(vec4 c)\n" +
785                    "{\n" +
786                    "    const vec4 K = vec4(1.0, 2.0 / 3.0, 1.0 / 3.0, 3.0);\n" +
787                    "    vec3 p = abs(fract(primaries2official(c.x) + K.xyz) * 6.0 - K.www);\n" +
788                    "    float v = (c.z + c.y * min(c.z, 1.0 - c.z));\n" +
789                    "    return vec4(v * mix(K.xxx, clamp(p - K.xxx, 0.0, 1.0), 2.0 * (1.0 - c.z / (v + eps))), c.w);\n" +
790                    "}";
791    /**
792     * This GLSL snippet takes an RGB vec3 and a float that represents a hue rotation in radians, and returns the
793     * rotated RGB vec3. It is not a full shader, and is used by inserting it into shader code to provide the applyHue()
794     * method to that code.
795     * <br>
796     * Credit for this challenging method goes to Andrey-Postelzhuk,
797     * <a href="https://forum.unity.com/threads/hue-saturation-brightness-contrast-shader.260649/">Unity Forums</a>.
798     */
799    public static final String partialHueRodrigues =
800            "vec3 applyHue(vec3 rgb, float hue)\n" +
801                    "{\n" +
802                    "    vec3 k = vec3(0.57735);\n" +
803                    "    float c = cos(hue);\n" +
804                    "    //Rodrigues' rotation formula\n" +
805                    "    return rgb * c + cross(k, rgb) * sin(hue) + k * dot(k, rgb) * (1.0 - c);\n" +
806                    "}\n";
807
808
809    /**
810     * Treats the color as hue, saturation, lightness, and... uh... well, this is pretty much only useful when the batch
811     * color's {@code a} is 1 . You probably want {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC} or {@link #fragmentShaderHSLA}.
812     * <br>
813     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
814     */
815    public static final String fragmentShaderHSL =
816            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
817                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
818                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
819                    "#else\n" +
820                    "#define LOWP \n" +
821                    "#endif\n" +
822                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
823                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
824                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
825                    partialCodeHSL +
826                    "void main()\n" +
827                    "{\n" +
828                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
829                    "   vec4 hsl = rgb2hsl(tgt);\n" +
830                    "   hsl.x = fract((fract(v_color.x + 0.5 - hsl.x) - 0.5) * v_color.w + hsl.x);\n" +
831                    "   hsl.yz = mix(hsl.yz, v_color.yz, v_color.w);\n" +
832                    "   gl_FragColor = hsl2rgb(hsl);\n" +
833                    "}";
834
835    /**
836     * I can't even remember what this does, to be honest. It's probably not what you want. Instead, you probably want
837     * {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC} or {@link #fragmentShaderHSLA}.
838     * <br>
839     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
840     */
841    public static final String fragmentShaderRotateHSL =
842            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
843                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
844                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
845                    "#else\n" +
846                    "#define LOWP \n" +
847                    "#endif\n" +
848                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
849                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
850                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
851                    partialCodeHSL +
852                    "void main()\n" +
853                    "{\n" +
854                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
855                    "   vec4 hsl = rgb2hsl(tgt);\n" +
856                    "   hsl.x = fract(v_color.x + hsl.x + 0.5);\n" +
857                    "   hsl.yz = clamp(hsl.yz * v_color.yz * 2.0, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
858                    "   gl_FragColor = hsl2rgb(hsl);\n" +
859                    "}";
860
861    /**
862     * This is similar to the default vertex shader from libGDX, but also sets a varying value for contrast. It is
863     * needed if you use {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC}.
864     */
865    public static final String vertexShaderHSLC = "attribute vec4 a_position;\n"
866            + "attribute vec4 a_color;\n"
867            + "attribute vec2 a_texCoord0;\n"
868            + "uniform mat4 u_projTrans;\n"
869            + "varying vec4 v_color;\n"
870            + "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" 
871            + "varying float v_lightFix;\n"
872            + "\n"
873            + "void main()\n"
874            + "{\n"
875            + "   v_color = a_color;\n"
876            + "   v_texCoords = a_texCoord0;\n"
877            + "   v_color.a = pow(v_color.a * (255.0/254.0) + 0.5, 1.709);\n"    
878            + "   v_lightFix = 1.0 + pow(v_color.a, 1.41421356);\n"
879            + "   gl_Position =  u_projTrans * a_position;\n"
880            + "}\n";
881
882    /**
883     * Allows changing Hue/Saturation/Lightness/Contrast, with hue as a rotation. If hue continuously goes from 0 to 1,
884     * then 0 to 1, 0 to 1, and so on, then this will smoothly rotate the hue of the image.
885     * <br>
886     * You can generate HSLC colors using methods like {@link FloatColors#rgb2hsl(float, float, float, float)}.
887     * <br>
888     * Credit for HLSL version goes to Andrey-Postelzhuk,
889     * <a href="https://forum.unity.com/threads/hue-saturation-brightness-contrast-shader.260649/">Unity Forums</a>.
890     * The YCC adaptation, and different approach to contrast (this has close to neutral contrast when a is 0.5,
891     * while the original had a fair bit higher contrast than expected), is from this codebase.
892     * <br>
893     * Meant only for use with {@link #vertexShaderHSLC}, which sets {@code varying float v_lightFix} so contrast can
894     * use it.
895     */
896    public static final String fragmentShaderHSLC = 
897                    "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
898                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
899                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
900                    "#else\n" +
901                    "#define LOWP \n" +
902                    "#endif\n" +
903                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
904                    "varying float v_lightFix;\n" +
905                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
906                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
907                            partialHueRodrigues +
908                    "void main()\n" +
909                    "{\n" +
910                    "    float hue = 6.2831853 * (v_color.x - 0.5);\n" +
911                    "    float saturation = v_color.y * 2.0;\n" +
912                    "    float brightness = v_color.z - 0.5;\n" +
913                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
914                    "    tgt.rgb = applyHue(tgt.rgb, hue);\n" +
915                    "    tgt.rgb = vec3(\n" +
916                    "     (0.5 * pow(dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125)), v_color.w) * v_lightFix + brightness),\n" + // lightness
917                    "     ((tgt.r - tgt.b) * saturation),\n" + // warmth
918                    "     ((tgt.g - tgt.b) * saturation));\n" + // mildness
919                    "    gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(\n" +
920                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, 0.625, -0.5)),\n" + // back to red
921                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, 0.5)),\n" + // back to green
922                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, -0.5)),\n" + // back to blue
923                    "     tgt.a), 0.0, 1.0);\n" + // keep alpha, then clamp
924                    "}";
925    /**
926     * Allows changing Hue/Saturation/Lightness/Alpha, with hue as a rotation.
927     * <br>
928     * You can generate HSLA colors using methods like {@link FloatColors#rgb2hsl(float, float, float, float)}.
929     * <br>
930     * Credit for HLSL version goes to Andrey-Postelzhuk,
931     * <a href="https://forum.unity.com/threads/hue-saturation-brightness-contrast-shader.260649/">Unity Forums</a>.
932     * The YCC adaptation, and change to use alpha, is from this codebase.
933     * <br>
934     * Meant to be used with {@link #vertexShader}, unlike what {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC} expects.
935     */
936    public static final String fragmentShaderHSLA = 
937                    "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
938                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
939                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
940                    "#else\n" +
941                    "#define LOWP \n" +
942                    "#endif\n" +
943                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
944                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
945                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
946                            partialHueRodrigues +
947                    "void main()\n" +
948                    "{\n" +
949                    "    float hue = 6.2831853 * (v_color.x - 0.5);\n" +
950                    "    float saturation = v_color.y * 2.0;\n" +
951                    "    float brightness = v_color.z - 0.5;\n" +
952                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
953                    "    tgt.rgb = applyHue(tgt.rgb, hue);\n" +
954                    "    tgt.rgb = vec3(\n" +
955                    "     (dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125)) + brightness),\n" + // lightness
956                    "     ((tgt.r - tgt.b) * saturation),\n" + // warmth
957                    "     ((tgt.g - tgt.b) * saturation));\n" + // mildness
958                    "    gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(\n" +
959                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, 0.625, -0.5)),\n" + // back to red
960                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, 0.5)),\n" + // back to green
961                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, -0.5)),\n" + // back to blue
962                    "     tgt.a * v_color.w), 0.0, 1.0);\n" + // keep alpha, then clamp
963                    "}";
964    /**
965     * Generally a lower-quality hue rotation than {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC}; this is here as a work in progress.
966     * <br>
967     * You can generate HSLC colors using methods like {@link FloatColors#rgb2hsl(float, float, float, float)}.
968     * <br>
969     * Meant to be used with {@link #vertexShaderHSLC}, which sets {@code varying float v_lightFix} so
970     * contrast can use it.
971     * <br>
972     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
973     */
974    public static final String fragmentShaderHSLC2 = 
975                    "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
976                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
977                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
978                    "#else\n" +
979                    "#define LOWP \n" +
980                    "#endif\n" +
981                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
982                    "varying float v_lightFix;\n" +
983                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
984                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
985                            partialCodeHSL +
986                    "void main()\n" +
987                    "{\n" +
988                    "    float hue = (v_color.x - 0.5);\n" +
989                    "    float saturation = v_color.y * 2.0;\n" +
990                    "    float brightness = v_color.z - 0.5;\n" +
991                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
992                    "    tgt = rgb2hsl(tgt);\n" +
993                    "    tgt.r = fract(tgt.r + hue);\n" +
994                    "    tgt = hsl2rgb(tgt);\n" +
995                    "    tgt.rgb = vec3(\n" +
996                    "     (0.5 * pow(dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125)), v_color.w) * v_lightFix + brightness),\n" + // lightness
997                    "     ((tgt.r - tgt.b) * saturation),\n" + // warmth
998                    "     ((tgt.g - tgt.b) * saturation));\n" + // mildness
999                    "    gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(\n" +
1000                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, 0.625, -0.5)),\n" + // back to red
1001                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, 0.5)),\n" + // back to green
1002                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, -0.5)),\n" + // back to blue
1003                    "     tgt.a), 0.0, 1.0);\n" + // keep alpha, then clamp
1004                    "}";
1005    /**
1006     * Cycles lightness in a psychedelic way as hue and lightness change; not a general-purpose usage.
1007     * <br>
1008     * You can generate HSLC colors using methods like {@link FloatColors#rgb2hsl(float, float, float, float)}.
1009     * <br>
1010     * Meant to be used with {@link #vertexShaderHSLC}, which sets {@code varying float v_lightFix} so
1011     * contrast can use it.
1012     * <br>
1013     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
1014     */
1015    public static final String fragmentShaderHSLC3 =
1016            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
1017                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
1018                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
1019                    "#else\n" +
1020                    "#define LOWP \n" +
1021                    "#endif\n" +
1022                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
1023                    "varying float v_lightFix;\n" +
1024                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
1025                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
1026                    partialHueRodrigues +
1027                    "void main()\n" +
1028                    "{\n" +
1029                    "    float hue = 6.2831853 * (v_color.x - 0.5);\n" +
1030                    "    float saturation = v_color.y * 2.0;\n" +
1031                    "    float brightness = v_color.z - 0.5;\n" +
1032                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
1033                    "    tgt.rgb = applyHue(tgt.rgb, hue);\n" +
1034                    "    tgt.rgb = vec3(\n" +
1035                    "     (0.5 * pow(dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(0.375, 0.5, 0.125)), v_color.w) * v_lightFix),\n" + // lightness
1036                    "     ((tgt.r - tgt.b) * saturation),\n" + // warmth
1037                    "     ((tgt.g - tgt.b) * saturation));\n" + // mildness
1038                    "    tgt.r = sin((tgt.r + brightness) * 6.2831853) * 0.5 + 0.5;\n" +
1039                    "    gl_FragColor = clamp(vec4(\n" +
1040                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, 0.625, -0.5)),\n" + // back to red
1041                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, 0.5)),\n" + // back to green
1042                    "     dot(tgt.rgb, vec3(1.0, -0.375, -0.5)),\n" + // back to blue
1043                    "     tgt.a), 0.0, 1.0);\n" + // keep alpha, then clamp
1044                    "}";
1045    /**
1046     * Cycles hue, but not lightness; otherwise this is like {@link #fragmentShaderHSLC3} without contrast, and keeping
1047     * alpha intact. Internally, this uses Sam Hocevar's RGB/HSL conversion instead of Andrey-Postelzhuk's HSLC code.
1048     * <br>
1049     * You can generate HSLA colors using methods like {@link FloatColors#rgb2hsl(float, float, float, float)}.
1050     * <br>
1051     * Expects the vertex shader to be {@link #vertexShader}, not the HSLC variant.
1052     * <br>
1053     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
1054     */
1055    public static final String fragmentShaderHSL4 =
1056            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
1057                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
1058                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
1059                    "#else\n" +
1060                    "#define LOWP \n" +
1061                    "#endif\n" +
1062                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
1063                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
1064                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
1065                    partialCodeHSL +
1066                    "void main()\n" +
1067                    "{\n" +
1068                    "    float hue = v_color.x - 0.5;\n" +
1069                    "    float saturation = v_color.y * 2.0;\n" +
1070                    "    float brightness = v_color.z - 0.5;\n" +
1071                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
1072                    "    tgt = rgb2hsl(tgt);\n" +
1073                    "    tgt.x = fract(tgt.x + hue);\n" +
1074                    "    tgt.y = clamp(tgt.y * saturation, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
1075                    "    tgt.z = clamp(brightness + tgt.z, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
1076                    "    gl_FragColor = hsl2rgb(tgt);\n" +
1077                    "}";
1078
1079    /**
1080     * One of the more useful HSL shaders here, this takes a batch color as hue, saturation, lightness, and power,
1081     * with hue as a target hue and power used to determine how much of the target color should be used. There is no
1082     * neutral value for hue, saturation, or lightness, but if power is 0, then the source color will be used
1083     * exactly. On the other hand, if power is 1.0, then all pixels will be the target color. Hue is specified from
1084     * 0.0 to 1.0, with 0.0 as red, about 0.3 as green, about 0.6 as blue, etc. Saturation is specified from 0.0 to 1.0,
1085     * with 0.0 as grayscale and 1.0 as a fully-saturated target color. Lightness is specified from 0.0 to 1.0, with 0.0
1086     * as black, the 0.3 to 0.7 range as most colors, and 1.0 white; saturation is clamped to a smaller value as
1087     * lightness moves away from 0.5 (toward black or white).
1088     * <br>
1089     * Expects the vertex shader to be {@link #vertexShader}, not the HSLC variant.
1090     * <br>
1091     * You can generate HSL(P) colors using methods like {@link FloatColors#rgb2hsl(float, float, float, float)}.
1092     */
1093    public static final String fragmentShaderHSLP =
1094            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
1095                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
1096                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
1097                    "#else\n" +
1098                    "#define LOWP \n" +
1099                    "#endif\n" +
1100                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
1101                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
1102                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
1103                    partialCodeHSL +
1104                    "void main()\n" +
1105                    "{\n" +
1106                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
1107                    "   vec4 hsl = rgb2hsl(tgt);\n" +
1108                    "   hsl.x *= 6.2831853;\n" +
1109                    "   hsl.xy = vec2(cos(hsl.x), sin(hsl.x)) * hsl.y;\n" +
1110                    "   vec3 tint = vec3(cos(v_color.x * 6.2831853) * v_color.y, sin(v_color.x * 6.2831853) * v_color.y * 2.0, v_color.z);\n" +
1111                    "   hsl.xyz = mix(hsl.xyz, tint, v_color.w);\n" +
1112                    "   hsl.xy = vec2(fract(atan(hsl.y, hsl.x) / 6.2831853), length(hsl.xy));\n" +
1113                    "   gl_FragColor = hsl2rgb(hsl);\n" +
1114                    "}";
1115
1116    /**
1117     * This is supposed to look for RGBA colors that are similar to {@code search}, and if it finds
1118     * one, to replace it with {@code replace} (also an RGBA color). It isn't great at the searching part.
1119     * <br>
1120     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
1121     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
1122     * <br>
1123     * EXPERIMENTAL. Meant more for reading and editing than serious usage.
1124     */
1125    public static final String fragmentShaderReplacement = 
1126                    "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
1127                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
1128                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
1129                    "#else\n" +
1130                    "#define LOWP \n" +
1131                    "#endif\n" +
1132                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
1133                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
1134                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
1135                    "uniform vec4 u_search;\n" +
1136                    "uniform vec4 u_replace;\n" +
1137                    "void main()\n" +
1138                    "{\n" +
1139                    "   vec4 tgt = texture2D(u_texture, v_texCoords);\n" +
1140                    "   float curve = smoothstep(0.0, 1.0, 1.25 - distance(tgt.rgb, u_search.rgb) * 2.0);\n" +
1141                    "   gl_FragColor = vec4(mix(tgt.rgb, u_replace.rgb, curve), tgt.a) * v_color;\n" +
1142                    "}";
1143    /**
1144     * A drop-in replacement for the default fragment shader that eliminates lightness differences in the output colors.
1145     * Specifically, it does the normal SpriteBatch shader's step with the multiplicative batch color, converts to IPT,
1146     * sets intensity to 0.5, shrinks the P and T components so the color is less saturated, and then converts back to
1147     * an RGBA color. Even though this uses IPT internally, it expects the batch color to be normal RGBA.
1148     * <br>
1149     * Editing this shader is strongly encouraged to fit your needs!
1150     * <br>
1151     * You can generate RGB colors using any of various methods in the {@code rgb} package, such as
1152     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)}.
1153     * <br>
1154     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
1155     * @see #fragmentShaderConfigurableContrast a per-sprite-configurable version of this
1156     */
1157    public static String fragmentShaderFlatLightness =
1158  "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
1159  "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
1160  "precision mediump float;\n" +
1161  "#else\n" +
1162  "#define LOWP \n" +
1163  "#endif\n" +
1164  "#define TARGET_LIGHTNESS 0.5 \n" +
1165  "#define SATURATION_CHANGE 1.0 \n" +
1166  "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
1167  "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
1168  "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
1169  "void main()\n" +
1170  "{\n" +
1171  "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
1172  "    vec3 ipt = (mat3(0.189786, 0.669665 , 0.286498, 0.576951, -0.73741 , 0.655205, 0.233221, 0.0681367, -0.941748)\n" +
1173  "         * (tgt.rgb * v_color.rgb));\n" +
1174  "    ipt.x = TARGET_LIGHTNESS;\n" + // change to desired lightness or pass in a lightness as a uniform
1175  "//    ipt.x = (ipt.x - 0.5) * 0.25 + TARGET_LIGHTNESS;\n" + // an alternative way that preserves a tiny bit of original lightness
1176  "    ipt.yz *= SATURATION_CHANGE;\n" + // multiplies saturation by SATURATION_CHANGE, which may be more or less than 1.0
1177  "    vec3 back = clamp(mat3(0.999779, 1.00015, 0.999769, 1.07094, -0.377744, 0.0629496, 0.324891, 0.220439, -0.809638) * ipt, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
1178  "    gl_FragColor = vec4(back, v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
1179  "}";
1180    /**
1181     * A specialized shader that can reduce lightness differences in the output colors, saturate/desaturate them, and
1182     * can be configured to use some of the existing lightness in the image to add to a main flat lightness.
1183     * Specifically, it takes the fragment color (typically a pixel in a texture), converts to IPT, does a calculation
1184     * involving the intensity of the fragment color where the batch color's blue channel affects how much that
1185     * intensity is used, adds the red channel of the batch color, multiplies the P and T components by the green
1186     * channel times 2.0 to saturate or desaturate, and then converts back to an RGBA color. The neutral value for this
1187     * is the RGBA color 0.5, 0.5, 1.0, 1.0 . A typical usage to achieve a fog effect would be to raise lightness (r),
1188     * slightly reduce saturation (g), sharply flatten the original texture's lightness (b), and leave alpha alone (a):
1189     * 0.7, 0.4, 0.2, 1.0 .
1190     * <br>
1191     * This doesn't use a standard type of color; you should use something like
1192     * {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.rgb.ColorTools#rgb(float, float, float, float)} to set the channels in
1193     * the specific way this uses them.
1194     * <br>
1195     * Meant for use with {@link #vertexShader}.
1196     * @see #fragmentShaderFlatLightness if you only need one contrast setting and still want to set color tints
1197     */
1198    public static String fragmentShaderConfigurableContrast =
1199            "#ifdef GL_ES\n" +
1200                    "#define LOWP lowp\n" +
1201                    "precision mediump float;\n" +
1202                    "#else\n" +
1203                    "#define LOWP \n" +
1204                    "#endif\n" +
1205                    "varying vec2 v_texCoords;\n" +
1206                    "varying LOWP vec4 v_color;\n" +
1207                    "uniform sampler2D u_texture;\n" +
1208                    "void main()\n" +
1209                    "{\n" +
1210                    "    vec4 tgt = texture2D( u_texture, v_texCoords );\n" +
1211                    "    vec3 ipt = (mat3(0.189786, 0.669665 , 0.286498, 0.576951, -0.73741 , 0.655205, 0.233221, 0.0681367, -0.941748)\n" +
1212                    "         * tgt.rgb);\n" +
1213                    "    ipt.x = (ipt.x - 0.5) * v_color.b + v_color.r;\n" + // preserves some lightness based on b, sets main lightness with r
1214                    "    ipt.yz *= v_color.g * 2.0;\n" + // the green channel affects saturation; if it's 0.5 it won't change saturation.
1215                    "    vec3 back = clamp(mat3(0.999779, 1.00015, 0.999769, 1.07094, -0.377744, 0.0629496, 0.324891, 0.220439, -0.809638) * ipt, 0.0, 1.0);\n" +
1216                    "    gl_FragColor = vec4(back, v_color.a * tgt.a);\n" +
1217                    "}";
1218
1219    /**
1220     * A day/night cycle shader that can be used without any other parts of this library. This only needs setting the
